üëã Good Friday morning and happy National Bagel Day ü•Ø!

Today, we‚Äôre launching a new podcast: Jewish Insider LLP (Limited Liability Podcast) is a new weekly podcast co-hosted by Rich Goldberg and Jarrod Bernstein.

Rich is a Republican and served as the director for countering Iranian weapons of mass destruction on the White House National Security Council during the Trump administration. He previously worked as chief of staff to former Illinois Gov. Bruce Rauner and deputy chief of staff to former Sen. Mark Kirk (R-IL).

Jarrod is a Democrat and served as the director of Jewish outreach (aka Jewish liaison) during the Obama administration. He also worked for former Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg.

Each week, Rich and Jarrod will share their perspectives on the latest news driving the conversation and have deep discussions with guests from across the political spectrum. This week‚Äôs guest is freshman Rep. Ritchie Torres (D-NY). More highlights below.

Subscribe to JI‚Äôs Limited Liability Podcast: iTunes | Spotify | Stitcher

Check out Jewish Insider‚Äôs latest ‚ÄòJewish Nielsen‚Äô report to see which webcasts people tuned into over the last several weeks.

Podcast playback

Ritchie Torres vows to prevent the ‚ÄòCorbynization‚Äô of progressive politics

Congressman Ritchie Torres (D-NY) cautioned about the rise of antisemitism in progressive politics during a wide-ranging conversation in the inaugural episode of Jewish Insider‚Äôs ‚ÄúLimited Liability Podcast,‚Äù hosted by Rich Goldberg and Jarrod Bernstein.

Man on a mission: Torres, who describes himself as ‚Äúthe embodiment of a pro-Israel progressive,‚Äù said he is mindful of anti-Israel elements within the Democratic Party that have the ability to turn antisemitic. ‚ÄúWe have an obligation to combat antisemitism no matter where it emerges, whether it‚Äôs from the right, from the left. It has to be fought at every turn and in every form,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúMy concern is that the pro-BDS left could be to the Democratic Party in American politics what Jeremy Corbyn has been to the Labour Party in British politics,‚Äù Torres cautioned. ‚ÄúIt only takes a few demagogues to pump antisemitic poison into the bloodstream of a political party. And so I see it as my mission to resist the Jeremy Corbynization of progressive politics in the United States.‚Äù

Sending a message: Torres, a freshman representing New York‚Äôs 15th congressional district, addressed his hard-fought primary victory, which pitted him against a diverse group of Democratic candidates, from the conservative Rub√©n D√≠az, Sr. to Democratic socialist Samelys L√≥pez. ‚ÄúI had powerful forces arrayed against me ‚Äî I had Bernie Sanders, [Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez], the [Working Families Party], the DSA, all endorsed Samelys L√≥pez against me. And not only did I win, but I won decisively,‚Äù Torres said of his primary victory. ‚ÄúAnd I sent a powerful message that you can run as a pro-Israel, pragmatic progressive without catering to the extremes and you can win decisively in a place like the South Bronx.‚Äù

Ground zero: ‚ÄúNew York City has become Ground Zero for Democratic socialism. In the latest election cycle, the [Democratic Socialists of America] won every single race in which it endorsed, except mine,‚Äù Torres noted. The former city councilmember seems intent on reversing that trend, endorsing the New York City mayoral run of Andrew Yang on Thursday morning. ‚ÄúLike myself, Andrew Yang is an idiosyncratic progressive,‚Äù Torres explained in the podcast.

Approach to Iran: Asked about re-entering the Iran nuclear deal, Torres told Goldberg and Bernstein that ‚Äúwe should negotiate a better deal rather than maintain the status quo.‚Äù He later added, ‚ÄúI would have concerns with arbitrarily lifting the sanctions and the effect had of releasing funds that could subsidize terrorism against Israel and our allies in the region.‚Äù

Listen to the full episode here.

Sky miles

All aboard ‚ÄòAir Adelson‚Äô

Sheldon Adelson‚Äôs Airbus A345 touched down at Tel Aviv‚Äôs Ben-Gurion Airport yesterday, after completing the late casino magnate‚Äôs last flight aboard one of his beloved private jets. It was a fitting final journey for Adelson, who died this week at age 87 and will be laid to rest in Jerusalem today in the presence of his immediate family. Jewish Insider‚Äòs Amy Spiro spoke to a handful of people about their own experiences aboard one of Adelson‚Äôs planes.

Message delivered: Abraham Foxman, the former national director of the Anti-Defamation League, told JI that he flew aboard Adelson‚Äôs jets on numerous occasions. But one specific journey, he said, stands out. ‚ÄúThe first week of December, the year that President George W. Bush was elected, I flew to the West Coast for a series of speeches,‚Äù said Foxman. ‚ÄúAs I arrived in Vegas to meet with the Adelsons, I received an invite to meet with the president on Tuesday.‚Äù Foxman said he told Adelson about the invitation, but noted that he wouldn‚Äôt be able to make it to the White House due to prior commitments. ‚ÄúHe said, ‚ÄòOh no ‚Äî I will fly you in one of my planes round-trip ‚Äî on condition you tell the president how you got there,‚Äô‚Äù Foxman recalled. ‚ÄúI went and delivered the message.‚Äù

Round trip: In 2015, Israeli basketball star Omri Casspi and his friend, investor and serial entrepreneur David Schottenstein, set out to bring a planeload of NBA stars and other celebrities to Israel to experience the country firsthand. But they wondered just how to transport them. ‚ÄúSomeone connected Omri to Miriam and Sheldon, and let them know that there was this effort to try and bring NBA players to Israel,‚Äù Schottenstein recounted to JI. The couple immediately agreed to provide a plane round-trip to Tel Aviv for the project, and repeated the offer when the trip recurred in 2016. ‚ÄúThey provided everything,‚Äù said Schottenstein. ‚ÄúIt really was amazing how we had this vision to do this trip, and the Adelsons were like ‚Äòwhatever you need, we‚Äôre here for you guys, we‚Äôll make it happen.‚Äô‚Äù

Saving lives: Earlier this year, one of the Adelson planes made a special flight from Miami to Tel Aviv to bring home Eli Beer, the president and founder of United Hatzalah, after he spent more than a month in a Miami hospital battling COVID-19, including a period in an induced coma. Once he recovered enough to travel home to his wife and children, Beer said, the Adelsons immediately offered to send him to Israel via one of their planes. ‚ÄúI had a lot of people that offered planes, but I knew that if Sheldon sent a plane, it‚Äôs not going to be taken off of his charity to Hatzalah ‚Äî it would be in addition,‚Äù Beer said. ‚ÄúMiriam said to me, ‚ÄòSheldon really, really wants to help Eli go back to saving lives.‚Äô That made me cry.‚Äù

Read the full feature here.

Bonus: A range of figures in the nonprofit world spoke to Jewish Insider‚Äôs Debra Nussbaum Cohen about their experiences with Adelson‚Äôs philanthropy and community activism. David Brog, CEO of the Maccabee Task Force, told JI that something Adelson told him at the launch of the task force has stuck with him for years: ‚ÄúHe said that his legacy is not going to be the casinos he built or money he earned, but what he did for Israel and the Jewish people. ‚ÄòThis work is my legacy,‚Äô he said. It wasn‚Äôt just talk.‚Äù Read more here.

Book Bind

U.N. agency head admits printing ‚Äòinappropriate‚Äô content in Palestinian classroom materials

The head of the U.N. agency tasked with providing support to Palestinians acknowledged on Thursday that learning materials widely distributed in Gaza and West Bank schools contained ‚Äúinappropriate‚Äù content glorifying Palestinian militants and encouraging violence, Jewish Insider‚Äôs Melissa Weiss reports.

Background: The U.N. Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA) printed and distributed its own materials to complement the Palestinian Authority‚Äôs curriculum. The materials, which repeatedly refer to Israel as ‚Äúthe enemy,‚Äù also include instructions in a math workbook for students to select the correct number of ‚Äúmartyrs‚Äù from the first intifada. A grammar booklet published by UNRWA includes the sentences, ‚ÄúJihad is one of the doors to Paradise,‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Palestinians have become an example of sacrifice.‚Äù

Apology tour: In a series of tweets, UNRWA Commissioner General Philippe Lazzarini indicated that the material in question was distributed in error, and that the agency had replaced the offending pages with ‚Äúcontent that adheres to U.N. values.‚Äù Lazzarini‚Äôs tweets came in the wake of a report by IMPACT-se, a watchdog organization that monitors content in educational materials distributed in schools throughout the Middle East.

Reaction: ‚ÄúThis avoidance of peace education is absolutely appalling. A U.N. organization has to teach the children to whom it has a duty of care about the possibility of peace,‚Äù Marcus Sheff, CEO of IMPACT-se, told JI. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt just avoid it. They make absolutely no effort whatsoever to do that.‚Äù

Eye on Washington: The Trump administration withdrew its funding from the U.N. agency in 2018. President-elect Joe Biden has said that he will restore aid to the Palestinian Authority that was cut off by the current administration, but has not specified whether that incudes aid to UNRWA. In 2017, the U.S. accounted for roughly one-third of the aid given to the organization, which spends more than 50% of its budget on education.
